ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I went from speaking zero French to being able to (I think) survive in a French speaking country if I was alone.

Lots of French grammar and vocabulary. We learned to conjugate in the present tense, le pass compos, and l'imparfait. We learned to talk about ourselves and others, our family, jobs, school, our childhood, and much more.

I have gained the ability to speak, write, read, and comprehend an elementary level of french. I feel that I now know how to listen and read best of all, but producing language comes with continued practice and time.
I learned important basic structural knowledge of the French language, including vocabulary, past tenses, verb conjugation, and sentence structure in French.

- basic framework for understanding and speaking french
- basic vocabulary and grammar for elementary french speaking

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would have appreciated a bit more organization to make sure I was staying on top of all of the assignments and when they were due - mostly just having canvas reflect the course packet

French in Action might be somewhat controversial, but it has been very effective. (As I understand it, they are not using French in Action next year, but I thought I should say that anyway.) The real strength of the course, however, is how Professor Ngame supplements the course material, and how the course itself is structured. The only thing I would change is maybe add one or two more opportunities for individual presentations or sketches (we only had two).

Very helpful to begin the course by focusing primarily on learning to speak (and pronounce) the language rather than just jumping into grammar straight away. Weekly oral tests were also very helpful in this.

Resources for the course are easy to access and concepts are not taught too quickly to understand. The biggest drawback from the current form of the course is the Capretz method. While the immersion aspect of the method was valuable, a large part of your engagement in the course depends on your engagement with the story being presented within the Capretz method. I personally did not find any interest in the story of Robert and Mireille, and I felt that my lack of interest in how the course was prevented sometimes began to hinder my learning.

Strengths:
- very extensive and in-depth
Weaknesses:
- very high workload, though arguably necessary to learning so much material in a short time span

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I had a lot of fun in this course.  We were all bad a French so we were just going for it.  You probably won't like it if you don't actually want to learn french, you'll just be annoyed at the work.  but if you do want to learn then you'll have a good time

Absolutely, as long as you are willing to put in the work. The course is fast paced, and it's easy to get behind on homework assignments, but you learn a LOT, and Professor Ngame is fantastic and makes the learning process fun. Having weekly tests (with a speaking portion) might be daunting, but it forces you to make sure the material is sinking in, and by the end of the course you realize how much you've learned as a result. If you want to learn French, there is no better way. (I really mean that. This is the fourth language I'm learning, and I've already learned more in one semester of French than I learned in several years of English and Spanish through more traditional methodology, i.e. classes twice a week or so, less of a focus on speaking, and no weekly tests.)

Yes! Especially with Professor Ngame, who really puts in the effort to make sure his students understand the material. Don't be put off by the high workload ratingFREN 110 is definitely a course where the harder you work, the better you will get. I thought the workload was definitely manageable in a 4.5 credit semester, since the only "hard" requirements for the class throughout the semester were the weekly workbook chapters, the weekly tests and the occasional composition. The tests really make you revise consistently, and by the time the final exam rolls around, you'll be glad you spent time on them. The level of satisfaction you have after learning how to speak, write and understand French in just one semester is amazing.

Yes, if a student is interested in learning how to speak french, I feel this course is an excellent introduction to the rigor it will take to truly become fluent. The intensity of the class matches the expectation that a student would have to achieve proficiency in just 5 semesters.
Yes! Very welcoming and efficient introductory level language class with a great professor!
Yes, this course teaches basic essentials and foundations of French. This class is essential if you want to learn the French language without any prior experience.
Yes, but only to students interested in learning french specifically, given the high workload.
